docs.title: SCADA Architecture & IIoT Standards
docs.text:
This site documents enterprise standards for:

  • SCADA architecture
  • Network design
  • Ignition development
  • IIoT data pipelines
  • Vendor onboarding

All projects and plants should align to these standards unless an approved Architecture Decision Record (ADR) exists.

docs.title: Architecture Decision Records (ADR)
docs.text: This section tracks major architecture decisions and their rationale.

docs.title: ADR List
docs.text: • ADR-0001 Use MQTT

docs.title: ADR 0001: Use MQTT Sparkplug B for OT Data Transport
Status
docs.text: Proposed

docs.title: Context
docs.text: Traditional OT data protocols (OPC UA, Modbus) are often "poll-response" based, which can saturate network bandwidth and lack efficient store-and-forward capabilities for unreliable WAN links. We need a modern, "publish-subscribe" protocol for cloud and enterprise ingestion.

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: We will adopt MQTT Sparkplug B as the enterprise standard for all northbound OT data transport from Level 3/3.5 to Level 4/5.

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
1. Report by Exception (RBE): Only changes data is sent, significantly reducing bandwidth usage.
  2. State Management: The "Birth" and "Death" certificate mechanism allows subscribers to know the health of the connection to the field device.
  3. Implicit Data Modeling: Sparkplug B provides a consistent payload format that includes metadata and units.
  4. Decoupling: Multiple subscribers (MES, BI, Cloud) can consume data from a single broker without increasing load on the PLC or SCADA gateway.
  5. Security: MQTT supports TLS/SSL encryption and certificate-based authentication.

docs.title: Consequences
docs.text:
• Tooling: All Edge Gateways must support Sparkplug B (e.g., Ignition Edge, Opto22, Telit).
  • Broker Infrastructure: High-availability MQTT brokers (e.g., HiveMQ, EMQX) must be deployed in the IDMZ.
  • Legacy Systems: Systems that do not support MQTT will require a gateway/bridge at Level 3.

docs.title: OT Data Flow Standards
docs.text: This document defines the standards for data movement across the OT network levels (Purdue Model) and into the enterprise cloud environments.

docs.title: Data Flow Architecture
docs.text: OT data flows are designed to be unidirectional (northbound) whenever possible, ensuring that higher-security zones are protected from lower-security zones or external networks.

docs.title: 1. Level 1 to Level 2 (Local Control)
docs.text:
• Protocol: EtherNet/IP, Profinet, Modbus TCP, OPC UA.
  • Direction: Bidirectional (Real-time control and monitoring).
  • Standard: PLCs communicate with local HMIs and SCADA Gateways within the same Cell/Area zone.

docs.title: 2. Level 2 to Level 3 (Site Operations)
docs.text:
• Protocol: OPC UA, SQL, Ignition Remote Provider.
  • Direction: Primary Northbound (Status/Alarms), Optional Southbound (Setpoint changes).
  • Standard: Data is aggregated from local SCADA nodes into Site-wide Historians and MES systems.

docs.title: 3. Level 3 to Level 3.5 (Industrial DMZ)
docs.text:
• Protocol: MQTT Sparkplug B over TLS/SSL.
  • Direction: Unidirectional Northbound.
  • Standard: Edge Gateways publish data to MQTT Brokers located in the IDMZ. No direct connection is allowed from the plant floor to the enterprise network.

docs.title: 4. Level 3.5 to Level 4/5 (Enterprise & Cloud)
docs.text:
• Protocol: MQTT, HTTPS (REST API), AMQP.
  • Direction: Unidirectional Northbound.
  • Standard: Enterprise brokers or cloud ingestion services (Azure IoT Hub, AWS IoT Core) subscribe to topics from the IDMZ brokers.

docs.title: Security Requirements for Data Flows
docs.text:
1. Protocol Isolation: Use gateways/proxies to bridge different network segments; never route raw industrial protocols (e.g., EtherNet/IP) across the IDMZ.
  2. Encryption: All data leaving Level 3 must be encrypted using TLS 1.2 or higher.
  3. Authentication: Use certificate-based authentication for MQTT clients and service principals for cloud ingestion.
  4. Firewall Conduits: Only specific, documented ports are allowed through firewalls (e.g., TCP 8883 for MQTTS).

docs.title: Purdue Model for Industrial Automation
docs.text: The Purdue Model is the foundation of enterprise OT architecture. It defines levels of control and IT systems, supporting deterministic operations, security zoning, and cloud integration.

docs.title: Levels Overview
docs.text: Purdue Level Zone Description L0 – Process Field Devices Sensors, actuators, motors, valves L1 – Basic Control PLCs / Controllers Real-time control loops, local logic L2 – Area / Cell HMIs, SCADA Local monitoring, operator interfaces, alarming L3 – Site Operations Historian, MES Data aggregation, reporting, manufacturing execution L3.5 – Industrial DMZ Edge & MQTT Brokers Secure buffer between OT and IT, cloud ingestion L4 – Enterprise IT ERP, Business Apps Planning, corporate reporting, dashboards L5 – Cloud / Analytics Azure, AWS, GCP AI/ML, BI, remote monitoring, energy management

docs.title: Network Segmentation Principles
docs.text:
• Each level is segmented using VLANs and firewalls.
  • Northbound traffic flows through controlled conduits.
  • No direct access from L4/L5 to L0/L1.
  • Industrial DMZ (L3.5) is the gateway for all cloud ingestion.

docs.title: Edge & Cloud Integration
docs.text:
Edge gateways collect data from PLCs / SCADA and publish via MQTT Sparkplug B to:

  • Local brokers in L3.5
  • Enterprise brokers in L3
  • Cloud ingestion pipelines (Azure IoT Hub, AWS IoT Core, GCP Pub/Sub)

This ensures:

  • Store-and-forward during WAN outages
  • Secure protocol isolation
  • No direct cloud-to-PLC paths

docs.title: Security Principles
docs.text:
• Apply Defense in Depth at every level.
  • Enforce least privilege on all accounts.
  • Maintain zone-based access controls.
  • Use MFA for remote access via DMZ jump hosts.
  • Logging and monitoring for all critical communications.

docs.title: SCADA & OT Architecture Standards Overview
docs.text: Welcome to the Enterprise Standards for Industrial Automation, SCADA, IIoT, and OT Cybersecurity.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
These standards provide a unified framework for designing, implementing, and maintaining Operational Technology (OT) systems across all manufacturing and processing facilities. By adhering to these standards, we ensure:

  • Security: Robust protection against cyber threats using the Defense in Depth strategy.
  • Reliability: High availability and redundancy for critical production systems.
  • Scalability: A modular architecture that grows with the enterprise.
  • Interoperability: Seamless data integration between the plant floor and enterprise systems.

docs.title: Core Architecture
docs.text: Based on the Purdue Model, defining the network levels and segmentation principles required for secure OT operations.

docs.title: SCADA & Ignition
docs.text: Detailed standards for deploying Ignition by Inductive Automation, including gateway configurations, redundancy, and project structures.

docs.text: Standards for data collection using Edge Gateways and transport via MQTT Sparkplug B.

docs.title: OT Cybersecurity
docs.text: Policies and technical controls for identity management, patching, and incident response following ISA/IEC 62443.

docs.text:

  • IT Professionals: For understanding OT-specific requirements and integration patterns.

docs.text:

  • All access authenticated and logged

docs.title: Security Zones & Conduits
docs.text: Following the ISA/IEC 62443 standard, our OT environment is divided into logical zones with defined conduits for communication.

docs.title: 1. Process Zone (Level 0-1)
docs.text: Contains the physical process equipment and controllers. - Assets: PLCs, I/O, Drives, Sensors. - Security: Physically secured, air-gapped or restricted to local HMI access.

docs.title: 2. Control Zone (Level 2)
docs.text: Contains visualization and local supervisor systems. - Assets: HMIs, SCADA Gateways, Engineering Workstations. - Security: VLAN segmentation, application whitelisting.

docs.title: 3. Operations Zone (Level 3)
docs.text: Site-wide systems for data aggregation and manufacturing execution. - Assets: Historians, MES servers, Asset Management. - Security: Domain-joined to local OT AD, restricted internet access.

docs.title: 4. Industrial DMZ (Level 3.5)
docs.text: The buffer zone between OT and IT networks. - Assets: MQTT Brokers, Jump Hosts, Proxy Servers. - Security: No passthrough traffic; all data must terminate and restart in the DMZ.

docs.title: Conduit Standards
docs.text:
Conduits are the communication paths between zones. Each conduit must be:

  1. Documented: Purpose, protocols, and port numbers.
  2. Authorized: Approved through the Change Management process.
  3. Restricted: Limited to the minimum necessary traffic (Least Privilege).

docs.title: Primary Conduits
docs.text: Source Zone Destination Zone Allowed Protocols Purpose Control (L2) Operations (L3) OPC UA, SQL Data Logging Operations (L3) IDMZ (L3.5) MQTTS (8883) Cloud Ingestion IT (L4) IDMZ (L3.5) RDP over TLS Remote Support

docs.title: Firewall Implementation
docs.text:
• Deny All by Default: Only explicitly allowed traffic is permitted.
  • Deep Packet Inspection (DPI): Used where possible for industrial protocols.
  • Logging: All conduit traffic is logged to the enterprise SIEM.

docs.title: How-To: Add a New Plant to the OT Infrastructure
docs.text: This guide outlines the standard onboarding process for integrating a new facility into our enterprise OT network.

docs.title: Phase 1: Planning & Network Setup
docs.text:
1. VLAN Request: Submit a request for the standard OT VLAN structure:
    • VLAN 10: Process/Control (L1-L2)
    • VLAN 20: Operations (L3)
    • VLAN 30: Security/Mgmt
  2. IP Allocation: Assign a reserved CIDR block from the enterprise OT IP plan.
  3. Firewall Rules: Configure the industrial firewall to allow traffic between the new site and the Enterprise DMZ (MQTTS, RDP).

docs.title: Phase 2: Infrastructure Deployment
docs.text:
1. Server Provisioning: Deploy standardized VM templates for:
    • Primary/Backup Ignition Gateways
    • Local SQL Historian
    • Asset Management Node
  2. OS Hardening: Apply enterprise OT GPOs and install approved security agents (Antivirus, Patch Mgmt).
  3. Active Directory: Join servers to the local OT Domain.

docs.title: Phase 3: Ignition & SCADA Setup
docs.text:
1. Installation: Install Ignition (LTS version) with the required modules.
  2. Gateway Configuration:
    • Configure Redundancy.
    • Setup Database and Historian connections.
    • Configure MQTT Engine and Transmission with enterprise broker credentials.
  3. Project Import: Import the standard Enterprise Template and Project structure.

docs.title: Phase 4: Verification
docs.text:
1. Data Flow Check: Verify tags are publishing to the enterprise MQTT broker.
  2. Remote Access Check: Test RDP access via the Jump Host.
  3. Security Scan: Perform an initial vulnerability scan and remediate high-risk findings.

docs.title: How-To: Standard Dashboard Deployment Process
docs.text: To ensure high availability and prevent production downtime, all Ignition Perspective dashboards must follow the standard Dev -> Staging -> Prod lifecycle.

docs.title: 1. Development Environment (Site-Level)
docs.text:
• Purpose: Feature development, UI prototyping, and initial tag binding.
  • Rules: Developers work on local "Dev" gateways or workstation designers.
  • Check: Use the Naming Conventions document for all component and view names.

docs.title: 2. Staging / QA Environment (Site or Enterprise)
docs.text:
• Purpose: Verification against live data and user acceptance testing (UAT).
  • Process:
    1. Export project/views from Dev.
    2. Import into Staging Gateway.
    3. Verify data bindings, security permissions, and responsive layout performance.
  • Approval: Operations lead must sign off on the dashboard functionality.

docs.title: 3. Production Deployment
docs.text:
• Process:
    1. Use the Ignition Enterprise Administration Module (EAM) to push resources to production gateways.
    2. Alternatively, perform a manual import during a scheduled maintenance window.
  • Monitoring: After deployment, monitor gateway logs for script errors or high tag-change rates.

docs.title: Version Control with Git
docs.text: All Ignition projects should be backed up using the external project-sync feature to a Git repository. - Commit Messages: Reference the Change Management ticket number. - Branching: Use feature/ branches and merge into main after UAT approval.

docs.title: Historian Integration Standards
docs.text: Standardizing how process data is archived and retrieved ensures data integrity and supports enterprise-wide analytics.

docs.title: Approved Historian Platforms
docs.text:
1. Site Level: Ignition Tag Historian (SQL-based) for short-term trending and local recovery.
  2. Enterprise Level: Aveva PI System (Asset Framework) for long-term archiving and complex calculations.
  3. Cloud Level: Azure Data Lake / AWS S3 for Big Data and AI/ML applications.

docs.title: SCADA to Site Historian
docs.text:
• Protocol: Native Ignition SQL Driver.
  • Storage: Minimum 1-year local retention on high-performance storage.
  • Redundancy: Use Store-and-Forward to prevent data loss during database outages.

docs.title: Site to Enterprise Historian (PI)
docs.text:
• Protocol: PI Connector for OPC UA or PI Interface for RDBMS.
  • Data Flow: Unidirectional from Level 3 to Level 4 via IDMZ.
  • Asset Framework (AF): All data must be mapped to a standardized AF template following the ISA-95 equipment hierarchy.

docs.title: OT to Cloud Ingestion
docs.text:
• Protocol: MQTT Sparkplug B.
  • Standard: Data is streamed in real-time to the cloud ingestion layer. Batch exports (CSV/Parquet) are permitted only for legacy systems.

docs.title: Data Governance
docs.text:
• Compression: Use "Exception and Compression" settings to minimize storage without losing process resolution.
  • Timestamps: All data must use UTC timestamps at the source.
  • Deadbands: Standard deadbands must be applied to prevent "noise" storage (e.g., 0.1% of span for analog values).

docs.title: Protocol
docs.text:
• MQTT v3.1.1 or v5
  • Sparkplug B required for OT data

docs.title: Naming Conventions
docs.text: Consistent naming across all plants and systems is critical for searchability, portability, and enterprise-wide reporting.

docs.title: Equipment Hierarchy (ISA-95)
docs.text:
Follow this structure for all tag and device naming: [Enterprise].[Site].[Area].[Line].[Cell].[Device]

Example: Tyson.PlantA.Processing.Line1.Filler.Motor01

docs.title: Tag Naming Standards
docs.text:
1. No Spaces: Use CamelCase or Underscores.
  2. Standard Suffixes: Use ISA-S5.1 standard abbreviations:
    • _PV: Process Value
    • _SP: Setpoint
    • _ST: Status
    • _ALM: Alarm
  3. Case Sensitivity: Consistent use of UpperCase for acronyms (e.g., PLC_Run_ST).

docs.title: PLC / Device Naming
docs.text:
Devices must be named based on their primary function and location: [Site]-[Area]-[Function]-[ID]

Example: PTA-PROB1-PLC-01 (Plant A, Processing Building 1, PLC #1)

  • project.db
  • project.alarm

No scripting in event handlers beyond function calls.

docs.title: Libraries
docs.text: All business logic must be in shared scripts.

docs.title: UDT First Strategy
docs.text:
• No direct PLC tags in screens
  • All equipment modeled as UDTs

docs.title: UDT Structure
docs.text:
Example: Pump

  • Cmd.Start
  • Cmd.Stop
  • Status.Running
  • Status.Fault
  • Alarms.*

docs.title: Instance Naming
docs.text:
Format:

Area_Equipment_Function

Example: PKG_P101_FeedPump

docs.title: Data Types
docs.text:
Type Use Float Process values Int Counts Bool States

No Strings from PLC unless required.

docs.title: Layout
docs.text:
• Follow corporate UI standards
  • Neutral background colors
  • High contrast for alarms

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
• No more than 3 clicks to reach equipment
  • Breadcrumb navigation required

docs.title: Templates
docs.text:
• All equipment uses templates
  • No copy-paste graphics

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
• No SQL queries in bindings
  • Use tag-driven views

docs.title: Mobile
docs.text: • Perspective views must support tablet resolution

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
All OT assets must be:

  • Identified
  • Classified
  • Version tracked

docs.title: Minimum Data
docs.text:
• Hostname
  • IP address
  • Firmware
  • Criticality

docs.title: Discovery
docs.text:
Approved methods:

  • Passive monitoring
  • Switch port mapping

docs.title: Monitoring
docs.text:
Alert on:

  • New devices
  • IP changes
  • Firmware changes

docs.title: Backup Scope
docs.text:
• PLC programs
  • HMI projects
  • SCADA gateways
  • Network configs

docs.title: Frequency
docs.text: System Backup PLC After changes SCADA Daily Network After config changes

docs.title: Storage
docs.text:
• Offline copy required
  • Immutable storage preferred

docs.title: Recovery Testing
docs.text:
• Annual restore tests
  • Document recovery time

docs.title: Audits
docs.text:
Annual review of:

  • Network segmentation
  • Firewall rules
  • Account management
  • Patch status

docs.title: Evidence
docs.text:
Maintain:

  • Architecture diagrams
  • Change logs
  • Incident reports

docs.title: Third-Party Reviews
docs.text:
Performed every:

2–3 years or after major changes

docs.title: Objectives
docs.text:
• Protect personnel, production, and equipment
  • Prevent cyber incidents impacting operations
  • Maintain regulatory and insurance compliance

docs.title: Standards Alignment
docs.text:
• IEC 62443 series
  • NIST SP 800-82
  • ISA-99

docs.title: Scope
docs.text:
Applies to:

  • PLCs
  • HMIs
  • SCADA servers
  • Edge gateways
  • OT network infrastructure

docs.title: Roles
docs.text: Role Responsibility OT Architect Architecture standards IT Security Policy enforcement Plant Engineering System maintenance Vendors Compliance with standards

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
• Central AD integration where possible
  • Local accounts only if isolated

docs.title: Authorization
docs.text:
Role-based access:

Role Example Access Operator View + acknowledge alarms Engineer Tag edits Admin Gateway config

docs.title: MFA
docs.text:
Required for:

  • VPN
  • Jump hosts
  • Cloud services

docs.title: Account Reviews
docs.text:
Quarterly review of:

  • Vendor accounts
  • Contractor access

docs.title: Objectives
docs.text:
• Protect safety first
  • Restore operations quickly
  • Preserve evidence

docs.title: Incident Types
docs.text:
• Malware detection
  • Network intrusion
  • Unauthorized access

docs.title: First Actions
docs.text:
1. Isolate affected zone
  2. Maintain control system stability
  3. Notify OT + IT security

docs.title: Forensics
docs.text:
• No re-imaging before evidence capture
  • Preserve logs and configs

docs.title: Recovery
docs.text:
• Rebuild from known-good backups
  • Validate before reconnecting

docs.title: Objectives
docs.text:
• Reduce exploit exposure
  • Avoid unplanned downtime

docs.title: Asset Classes
docs.text: Asset Patch Cycle Servers Quarterly HMIs Semi-annual PLCs As approved

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
All patches must be tested in:

DEV or TEST environment

docs.title: Vulnerability Scanning
docs.text:
• Passive scanning in OT only
  • No active scans on PLC networks

docs.title: Emergency Patching
docs.text:
Allowed only with:

OT + Operations approval

docs.title: Principles
docs.text:
• No always-on vendor access
  • Time-bound sessions only

docs.title: Approved Architecture
docs.text: Vendor → VPN → DMZ Jump Host → OT

docs.title: Controls
docs.text:
• MFA required
  • Session recording
  • Approval workflow

docs.title: Prohibited
docs.text:
• Direct VPN to control VLAN
  • Cellular modems on PLCs
  • Cloud remote desktop tools

docs.title: Zones
docs.text: Zone Examples Cell/Area PLCs, drives Control HMIs, SCADA Site Ops Historians, MES Industrial DMZ Brokers, jump hosts IT ERP, AD

docs.title: Conduits
docs.text:
Conduits must:

  • Be firewall-controlled
  • Have documented rules
  • Use least privilege

docs.title: Risk Classification
docs.text:
Each zone rated:

  • Low
  • Medium
  • High

Controls scale with risk level.
